sentence: The Dow Jones Industrial Average (DJI) couldn't quite capitalize on the news out of Greece this weekend, and ultimately fluttered most of the day near breakeven.
"The key driver today was definitely the Greek election turning out the way everyone wanted.
It's all we talked about," said Schaeffer's Senior Technical Strategist Ryan Detrick.
"Yet, the big question is, why didn't we rally more on this seemingly good news?
My take is, since we had such a big pop on Friday afternoon, and with the upcoming Fed decision slated for Wednesday, buyers took the day off."

Keep reading to see what else was on our radar today:
• Does the iPath S&P 500 VIX Short Term Futures Index ( VXX ) portend a volatility-prone summer on Wall Street ?
• Are traders buying equities in anticipation of another round of quantitative easing ?
• Look in on the SPDR Gold Trust ETF ( GLD ) and CBOE Market Volatility Index (VIX) open interest with Bernie Schaeffer.
And now, a look at the numbers...
The Dow Jones Industrial Average (DJI - 12,741.82) couldn't keep last week's momentum alive, and spent most of the session faltering just below breakeven.
By the time the dust settled, the Dow notched a modest 25.4-point, or 0.2%, deficit.
Nineteen of the 30 blue chips ended in negative territory, with Hewlett-Packard's ( HPQ ) 2.7% pullback leading the parade of laggards.
Kraft Foods ( KFT ) and Home Depot ( HD ) paced the winning issues with gains of nearly 0.9% apiece.
The S&P 500 Index (SPX - 1,344.78) was able to eke out a slight win today, adding 1.9 points, or 0.1%.
Meanwhile, the Nasdaq Composite (COMP - 2,895.33) posted the best performance of its fellow benchmarks, and settled with a 22.5-point, or 0.8%, rise.
The CBOE Market Volatility Index (VIX - 18.32) dropped for a third consecutive day, lopping off 13.22%, and landing just above its coming off its session low of 18.24.
This marks the VIX's lowest daily close since May 3.
Today's highlight : "We didn't see a hard sell-off for one," said Detrick "There was a time not too long ago that 'good news' was just an excuse to sell.
This could be seen as another sign that things could be changing and higher prices could be coming soon.
Lastly, it was very encouraging to see the SPX stay above the 1,333 level yet again," smiled Detrick.
• Bernie Schaeffer On Charts : Examining a spike in VIX open interest, and key trendline resistance for the SPDR Gold Trust ETF ( GLD ).
• Schaeffer's Equities Analyst Bryan Sapp contemplated today's divergence between stocks and the euro .
• E-commerce deals site Groupon (GRPN) and tech issue Rambus (RMBS) were targeted by analysts.
• July-dated long calls were used to bet on a near-term upswing for Smithfield Foods (SFD).
• An options players initiated a bear put spread on Adobe Systems (ADBE), while a bear call spread was started on Onyxx Pharmaceuticals (ONXX).
• Discounter Dollar General (DG) and high-end retailer Tiffany's & Co. (TIF) were among equities marking record-breaking runs today.
• VMware's (VMW) July 87.50 and July 90 calls were hot picks in the options pits today.
• High volatility in a usually inactive summer?
Schaeffer's Columnist Adam Warner revisited the iPath S&P 500 VIX Short Term Futures Index ( VXX ) .
For today's activity in commodities, options, and more, head to page 2.
Oil futures snapped their winning streak today, as anxieties continue to mount on Spanish debt and the overall fiscal health of the euro zone.
By the close, July-dated oil slipped 76 cents, or 0.9%, to land at $83.27 a barrel.
Gold futures dipped for the first session in six, but inched near breakeven before the closing bell, as investors sought safety on concerns about Spanish debt.
Plus, speculators are awaiting the results this week's Federal Open Market Committee meeting regarding monetary policy.
Gold for August delivery declined $1.10, or 0.1%, to settle at $1,627 an ounce.
